Explanation: Students will acquire knowledge of various topics in discrete mathematics, including logical notation, sets, relations, graph theory, and number theory.
Students will learn different proof techniques, such as induction and proofs by contradiction, to prove mathematical statements.
Students will gain knowledge of elementary analysis of algorithms, including asymptotic notation, to analyze the efficiency and performance of algorithms.
Students will acquire knowledge of elementary number theory and its applications in cryptography.
Students will learn about permutations and combinations and their applications in counting and combinatorial problems.
Students will acquire knowledge of the language and core concepts of probability theory.
Students will learn about various probability distributions, including Bernoulli, binomial, geometric, Poisson, uniform, normal, and exponential distributions.
Students will gain knowledge of statistical estimation techniques, including maximum likelihood estimation and confidence interval estimation.
Students will learn about simple linear regression and how to interpret and compute regression models.
Students will acquire knowledge of null hypothesis significance testing (NHST) and how to perform specific significance tests, such as z-tests, t-tests, and chi-squared tests.
Students will understand the role of abstraction in the design of large digital systems and be able to explain major software and hardware abstractions in contemporary computer systems.
Students will gain knowledge of the technical skills necessary to be a capable digital systems engineer.
Although not explicitly mentioned in the course description, students may gain knowledge of database design principles as they learn about designing digital systems.
Students will understand issues affecting microprocessor instruction set design.
Students will learn how to measure the memory access performance of a processor and tune cache design parameters to improve performance.
Students will acquire a foundational knowledge of programming, including programming concepts and principles.
Students will learn about fundamental computational concepts, such as algorithms, data structures, and problem-solving strategies.
Students will gain knowledge of software engineering principles and practices, including software design, construction, and implementation.
Students will learn the basics of the Python programming language, including syntax, data types, and control structures.
Students will develop knowledge and skills in solving abstract problems using programming techniques and concepts.
Students should have basic knowledge of discrete mathematics, including set theory, relations and logic, combinatorics, proofs, recursion, number theory, graph theory, and probability.
Although not explicitly mentioned in the course description, knowledge of database design principles may be useful for understanding and implementing certain algorithms.
Students will learn about different algorithmic paradigms, such as dynamic programming, greedy algorithms, and divide and conquer.
Students will learn how to analyze the performance of algorithms and understand basic performance measures.
Students will learn how to model computational problems mathematically and translate them into algorithms.
Students will learn about specifications and invariants in software development.
Students will learn about abstract data types and representation independence in software development.
Students will learn how to design a database.
Students will learn about version control and how to use it in software development.
Students will learn about code review and how to participate in the code reviewing process.
Students will gain familiarity with major algorithms and data structures.
Students will learn how to write rigorous correctness proofs for algorithms.
Students will understand what competitive analysis is and when it applies to algorithm design.
Students will be familiar with approximation algorithms and their benefits.
Students will learn about randomized algorithms and how to analyze them.
Students will learn to recognize and critique design choices made in existing systems.
Students will acquire knowledge of technical details necessary to design their own systems, including concepts such as abstraction, modularity, and virtualization.
Students will learn communication concepts and skills necessary for effective system design and analysis.
Students will gain knowledge of principles of computer system design, including techniques for controlling complexity, performance, security, and fault tolerance.

Students will learn about the theoretical foundations of computation, including the Church-Turing thesis, decidability, the halting problem, and reducibility.
Students will gain knowledge about the measures of complexity, complexity classes (P, NP, L, NL, PSPACE, BPP, IP), complete problems, hierarchy theorems, and probabilistic computation.
Students will learn about regular and context-free languages and their applications in computational theory.
